title: Monday, 3rd October, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Difficult to know where to start today, in the wake of Friday's historical call on Deutsche Bank

PM

Germany shut today, so we can't see the follow-thru impact there

11:03 am
PM

But all it took was the Elder Plan and some spurious 'news' on the possibility of a lower settlement with the DoJ, helpfully propagated by AFP

PM

The regulatory stuff is just a Chuck Rhoades gambit (spell?)

PM

The $14bn fig was just PR -- cos of the Apple tax thing

11:03 am
PM

Nothing more

PM

The DoJ settlement will be with multiple banks -- including Barclays

PM

And it will be low single figure billions

11:04 am
PM

You watch

PM

Anyway, well done Bryce

PM

An historic call

11:04 am
BE

Okay. I don't think we can underemphasise how stupid Friday afternoon was.

PM

Yeah, thoroughly stupid, but the price action was supportive

BE

So this $5.4bln figure seems to have popped up in a JP Morgan report

11:06 am
BE

And was picked up by some fifth-rate Twitter account, which was retweeted by four-rate Twitter accounts, whose retweets were picked up by Bloomberg's automated Twitter velocity noise-to-signal generator.

BE

Which seemed to bleed somehow onto AFP

PM

"Sources' Bryce, "sources"

11:07 am
BE

... Now, I'm not connecting that to it being a French newswire on a Friday afternoon ....... But, well, I've worked for them in the past and ......

PM

and....

BE

.... Anyway, the $5.4bn JPM report wasn't even referring to the DOJ fine.

11:07 am
PM

hehehehe

BE

It's an absolute clownshow.

PM

thumbs up

11:08 am
PM

We need a clown emoji

BE

We do. Whatever, we have a day without Deutsche and we should probably make the most of it. We'll be back in the circus tomorrow.

undefined
11:09 am
PM

So Brexit means leaving the european union

BE

Cripes! Really?

PM

That's today's big news

11:09 am
PM

Who'd have thought?

PM

Do we lead the FT reverse ferret on this?

PM

Terrific news, good for stocks, so long as you are valuing those stocks in GBK

11:10 am
BE

Okay ....... Well ......

PM

Krona at 1.287 on my screen

BE

And the FTSE absolutely soaring, of course. Up 1.2%, nudging back to 7k.

11:11 am
PM

It's a bull market

BE

Want to see some charts?

PM

Yeah!

11:11 am
BE

This is FTSE 100 since end 2011.

BE

BE

And here's the exact same chart priced in dollars.

11:11 am
BE

PM

oh omg smile

BE

You'll note, when using the more relevant currency, FTSE's down about 6% in 12 months

11:12 am
BE

And underperforming the MSCI World in $ terms

BE

BE

(12m normalised 12 month performance)

11:12 am
BE

FTSE also down nearly 5% since the day before the Brexit vote, in $

BE

And down 2.3% YTD.

PM

I fear you are stuck off-message Bryce

11:13 am
BE

Not at all! I'm very much on message that it's better than many indices.

BE

Such as the FTSE 250, which is down 9.4% YTD in $

PM

oh omg smile

11:13 am
BE

It's also better than Italy! MIB's down YTD by 21% in $

BE

Otherwise in Europe, you're questing a bit to find much we're outperforming.

BE

There's ..... um .......... Bosnia & Herzegovina?

11:14 am
BE

The BRIS is down 12% in $

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

After that you have to look at Nigeria, Venezuela, Kenya ..... all of which are down by serious %

11:14 am
BE

Still! Sunlit uplands.

PM

( Flaneur -- deep deep value hiding in plain sight)

undefined
11:15 am
PM

Forgot to put the pic up earlier

PM

PM

Yoshinori Ohsumi of Japan

11:16 am
BE

Guy who invented Mario?

PM

Won the Nobel for medicine for something i don't understand

BE

Oh.

11:16 am
BE

Apologies to both.

PM

Yeah, well done Yoshinori

PM

He actually looks like a Nobel winner

11:16 am
undefined
PM

And so to Henderson Group

Henderson Group PLC (HGG:LSE): Last: 260.20, up 28.2 (+12.16%), High: 278.80, Low: 259.40, Volume: 3.91m
11:17 am
PM

A merger of equals

Jupiter Fund Management PLC (JUP:LSE): Last: 444.16, up 18.76 (+4.41%), High: 446.70, Low: 426.20, Volume: 401.64k
BE

Heh. No it's not.

11:17 am
BE

The prices tell you that.

BE

What kind of merger of equals works by giving one side 57% of the combined company?

BE

For 40% of the total assets.

11:19 am
PM

It's that what's happening with Janus?

BE

Janus is being shut down in a way that doesn't embarrass its management

BE

And they're giving away a bunch of value to save face.

11:19 am
BE

It's a triumph.

PM

Bill Gross directly involved in this?

BE

Well, it's a bad deal but I don't think it's that bad.

11:20 am
BE

Want some Barclays to summarise?

PM

Sure

PM

But I'm just noting the greek god Janus

11:20 am
PM

Janus presided over the beginning and ending of conflict, and hence war and peace. The doors of his temple were open in time of war, and closed to mark the peace. As a god of transitions, he had functions pertaining to birth and to journeys and exchange, and in his association with Portunus, a similar harbor and gateway god, he was concerned with travelling, trading and shipping.

BE

........................... Uh, okay. I'm a half-educated tenement Scot. I didn't do classics.

BE

Here's Barclays.

11:21 am
BE

The deal initially seems better value from the HGG side since HGG only contributes 40% of the combined AUM (at $127bn of $322bn total) and is contributing only 48% of the combined EBITDA (at $337m for HGG of $698m total) yet is ending up with 57% of the combined company. This likely reflects HGG paper having a higher multiple and Janus’ more troubled outflow history. The rationale behind the deal is to enhance distribution reach for these complementary businesses, improve economies of scale and realise at least $110m of net cost synergies. The HGG shares are to be delisted from UK and only listed in the US and Australia. Accretion is detailed as double-digit in year 1, but synergies seem quite conservative set at only 7% of combined cost base ($110m to -$1.5bn). The transaction has been recommended by both boards and supported by Janus largest shareholder, Dai-Ichi Life, who propose to increase their stake. HGG has had poor flow momentum so far in 2016 with -£2bn of outflows, Janus has suffered large outflows in the period 2010-14, but recently has shown some evidence of turning these around.

BE

Rationale for merger - complementary investment strategies and geographical footprint

The management teams indicate several client-focused and structural drivers underpinning the rationale behind the transaction. The businesses complement one another in terms of investment capabilities and geographical footprint. Henderson’s strength in Europe and Global equities combined with Janus’ US Equity and Fixed income offering results in a well diversified entity offering a wider range of investment propositions. The expansion of client-facing teams will deepen relationships and distribution strategies. Structurally, the deal will offer economies of scale in an industry that is seeing rising costs and fee pressure. Overall the deal is viewed as a combination of two businesses with similar corporate strategies and complementary product offerings to serve an increasingly global client base.

BE

I hadn't realised how much Janus was bleeding.

11:23 am
BE

BE

Also note, savings of $110m. 16% of combined underlying EBITDA.

BE

How much is Bill Gross paid?

11:24 am
PM

I think it's around $110m

BE

Well, there's a quick fix.

PM

These US fund managers get clown-grade salaries

11:25 am
PM

Ive never understood why

BE

Note also the rather bulky management .....

PM

test

11:26 am
BE

Everyone gets a job, including co-CEOs.

undefined
BE

So .................. hi!

1:13 pm
BE

We had a bit of a bork.

BE

The FT Alphaville servers all fell over at about 11.30am and have only just been switched back on.

BE

But there's no bloody way we're picking up this session again.

1:16 pm
BE

So .... well, see you tomorrow I guess.

BE

We can only offer our usual apologies for circumstances outside our control, by which I mean the computers not working.

BE

To wrap up, here's that hamster-server picture we use sometimes.

1:18 pm
BE

BE

Come back Tuesday. Ta.

PM

I'm glad you've been keeping an eye on all this
